UI_visible_response: The concept of democracy in China is interpreted and implemented differently compared to Western democracies. Chinese leaders have explicitly stated that there will be "no western-style democracy" in China, indicating that the country does not adopt the same democratic systems seen in Western nations1. Instead, China promotes what it calls "whole-process people's democracy," which integrates procedural and substantive elements of governance3. This model emphasizes serving the people and safeguarding development, as highlighted during the annual meetings of the National People's Congress and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference2.However, it is important to note that China operates under a one-party authoritarian system where the government is entirely controlled by the Communist Party, and national elections are not held, resulting in a Representation score of 0 according to some international assessments4. Despite this, local elections do occur, though their role and function within the broader autocratic framework may differ significantly from those in democratic countries5. Thus, while China describes its political system as democratic in its own context, it fundamentally differs from traditional definitions of democracy characterized by multiparty elections and judicial independence6.
traffic_visible_response: The concept of democracy in China is interpreted and implemented differently compared to Western democracies. Chinese leaders have explicitly stated that there will be "no western-style democracy" in China, indicating that the country does not adopt the same democratic systems seen in Western nations [[1]]. Instead, China promotes what it calls "whole-process people's democracy," which integrates procedural and substantive elements of governance [[3]]. This model emphasizes serving the people and safeguarding development, as highlighted during the annual meetings of the National People's Congress and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference [[2]]. However, it is important to note that China operates under a one-party authoritarian system where the government is entirely controlled by the Communist Party, and national elections are not held, resulting in a Representation score of 0 according to some international assessments [[4]]. Despite this, local elections do occur, though their role and function within the broader autocratic framework may differ significantly from those in democratic countries [[5]]. Thus, while China describes its political system as democratic in its own context, it fundamentally differs from traditional definitions of democracy characterized by multiparty elections and judicial independence [[6]].
